Nigeria - Federal Universities Development
            Sector Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Federal Universities
            Development Sector Adjustment Credit Project for Nigeria
            were as follows: outcomes were unsatisfactory, project
            sustainability was uncertain, Bank performance was highly
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was also highly
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: adjustment
            credits are not effective mechanisms for promoting complex
            institutional and management reforms in higher education,
            and perhaps not in the health and education sectors
            generally. In order to safeguard quality objectives under
            higher education projects, explicit attention should be
            given to managing and monitoring unit costs per student as a
            key indicator of educational quality. Higher education
            project objectives should not only promote cost efficiency
            and effective resource allocation, but also the parallel
            need for establishing mechanisms and procedures for quality
            assurance. The diversity of university circumstances in
            Nigeria (e.g., size, mission, location, age) is too great to
            be encompassed by a single uniform set of eligibility
            criteria. Finally, project re-structuring can be an be an
            effective response to a poorly performing project.

repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - Federal Universities Development
            Sector Adjustment Operation

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall objective of the Federal
            Universities Development Sector Adjustment Credit Project is
            to assist the Government in its efforts to ensure that the
            federal universities will improve the effectiveness and
            relevance of their teaching and research while at the same
            time becoming more cost effective.  More specifically the
            program aims to : a) encourage universities to reduce the
            recurrent cost per student borne by the Government; b)
            increase internally generated income; c) reduce overstaffing
            and other areas of wastage; d) make more effective use of
            scarce resources available through funds transfers to areas
            more critical for quality teaching and research; e) help
            accelerate the pace of reequipping academic space; and f)
            strengthen institutions for planning, budgeting and procurement.
